front.div:
Abstract
A polylysine partially substituted with polyhydroxyalkanoyl residues and specially with gluconoyl residues was
developed in order to increase the transfection efficiency by decreasing the strength of the electrostatic interactions between
the DNA and the cationic polymer. Partially gluconoylated polylysine r DNA complexes were more easily dissociated in
solution and their transfection efficiency in the presence of chloroquine, evaluated with HepG2 cells, a human hepatocarci-
nomaline, was higher when 43 " 4% of the e-amino groups of polylysine were blocked with gluconoyl residues. Partially
gluconoylated polylysine r plasmid complexes were efficient intransfecting different adherent as well as non-adherent cell
Ž.
lines. Partially gluconoylated polylysine formed highly soluble above 100mg rmlin DNA complexes with DNA
plasmids. In addition, partially gluconoylated polylysine bearing few lactosyl residues increased the transfection efficiency
of HepG2 cells which express a galactose-specific membrane lectin.
